awd_titl_txt: Interdisciplinary Postdoctoral Fellowship in Behavioral and Forensic Sciences
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Interdisciplinary Postdoctoral Fellowship in Behavioral and Forensic Sciences

Abstract

This project will support an interdisciplinary postdoctoral fellow who will conduct research under the mentorship of senior scholars in the fields of behavior sciences and forensic sciences at Arizona State University. The past decade has seen the beginning of a major transformation in the field of forensic science. This postdoctoral fellow's research program will advance scientific understanding at the nexus of the behavioral sciences and forensic sciences, with a goal to improve how forensic science is developed, conducted, and communicated. 

This project will support a postdoctoral scholar who will be engaged in a number of research areas at Arizona State University?s Forensic Science Initiative Program and Law and Behavioral Science Program for two years. The research will involve developing ways to test the validity and reliability of forensic techniques, investigating the human side of forensic judgment, and helping non-scientists such as jurors, lawyers, and judges understand and evaluate the quality of forensic science by improving how it is communicated. The postdoctoral fellow will receive consistent and ongoing mentorship from a team of scholars with established research records in the area of the fellow?s work. The goal of this interdisciplinary postdoctoral fellowship is to facilitate the growth of a scholar working in a critically-understudied area at the intersection of the behavioral and forensic sciences, in order to advance scientific understandings of convergence of these important areas of study.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This Interdisciplinary Postdoctoral Fellowship grant provided funding for a postdoctoral scholar who would bridge the behavioral and forensic sciences and specifically use behavioral science research to gain a better understanding of the issues facing the forensic sciences. The need for such scholars became apparent with reports from the National Academy of Sciences and the President’s Council of Advisors on Science and Technology that pointed out systemic issues with the quality of certain types of forensic evidence (particularly those based on pattern matching). We successfully recruited a scholar – Dr. Bethany Growns – who joined our university for two years. In that time, Dr. Growns worked across our university’s Law and Behavioral Science and Future of Forensic Science initiatives on a series of projects examining how behavioral science theory can help explain, improve, and train forensic science pattern matching tasks. In addition, Dr. Growns assisted in coordinating several gatherings of national and international scholars working at the intersection of the behavioral and forensic sciences at our university. Further, Dr. Growns engaged in collaborative research with multiple faculty and students at our university resulting in several research publications and presentations. As a result of Dr. Growns’s work undertaken while funded by this award, significant advancement was made in establishing ongoing coordinated activities to keep bridging the behavioral and forensic sciences, including the formation of a new academic unit at our university (launching in late 2023) that brings forensic scientists together with psychologists and behavioral scientists working at the intersection of law and psychology with the goal of expanding and improving the use of science in the legal system.
